subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Attention Unicode pundits: Half-letters etc. in Unicode

messageBody:
Benct Philip Jonsson scripsit:

> Technically Unicode allows the insertion of invisible
> characters to enforce or prevent joining at any given point,
> but if I understand there must be a default of either
> joining or disjoining for any given script.

More precisely, every Unicode character has the property of being
left-joining, right-joining, dual-joining, or non-joining. Currently,
only Arabic, Syriac, and N'Ko characters have any property other than
non-joining; this list is expected to grow. The joining properties of
adjacent characters may or may not entail the substitution of alternative
glyphs for them.

Of the invisible characters, ZWJ (U+200D) is dual-joining (and therefore
forces the adjacent characters to join, if possible), whereas ZWNJ
(U+200C) is non-joining (and therefore forces the adjacent characters
to remain unjoined).

See http://www.unicode.org/Public/UNIDATA/ArabicShaping.txt
for details.

> Are there markers to indicate that joining should or should not take
> place in a given stretch of text rather than at a particular point
> in a text? Can joining or disjoining be set on a font basis and thus
> display with half-letters and alternate letter forms be left to the
> discretion of the *reader*?

No to both. Such things are left to higher levels of text processing
than plain Unicode.
